product_name: DrybarThe Single Shot Round Blow-Dryer Brush
summary: SummaryBlow-drying has never been easier! The Single Shot Round Blow-Dryer Brush from Drybar combines the hot air of a blow-dryer with the structure of a round brush to create waves, curls and a smooth, shiny blowout in one quick, simple step. Perfect for shorter hair styles!
details: DetailsFeaturesIonic Technology reduces frizz and adds tons of shine while stylingStrategically-placed vents provide maximum airflow for a faster blowoutErgonomic, lightweight design provides maximum comfortA combination of nylon and tufted bristles allows for exceptional tension and control2.25" round shape is perfect for shorter hair styles and creating loose waves and curls3 temperature settings (cool/medium/high) allows for customized styling of all hair typesGuaranteed with a 2-year limited warrantyItem 2577664How To UseAfter shampooing, thoroughly towel-dry hair to remove excess water.* Brush out hair using a detangling brush or comb, and separate into large sections. Place The Single Shot underneath each section and work it slowly from roots to ends, until the section is dry and smooth. For volume at the roots, use horizontally at the crown. The Single Shot can also be used on dry hair to create a smooth, finished look.For loose curls and waves, use vertically throughout the hair. For volume at the roots, use horizontally at the crown.*For extra-thick or long hair, it may be necessary to rough-dry hair with a regular blow-dryer before using The Single Shot.Shipping & Coupon RestrictionsThis brand is excluded from most Ulta Beauty coupons.See brand eligibility details
how_to_use: After shampooing, thoroughly towel-dry hair to remove excess water.* Brush out hair using a detangling brush or comb, and separate into large sections. Place The Single Shot underneath each section and work it slowly from roots to ends, until the section is dry and smooth. For volume at the roots, use horizontally at the crown. The Single Shot can also be used on dry hair to create a smooth, finished look.For loose curls and waves, use vertically throughout the hair. For volume at the roots, use horizontally at the crown.*For extra-thick or long hair, it may be necessary to rough-dry hair with a regular blow-dryer before using The Single Shot.

reviews.headline: OMG! I was pleasantly surprised!
reviews.comments: I have bought and tried many different hair tools and brands, some to great satisfaction. However this was the first i was overjoyed during and after first use. I have short , fine hair and it was sooooo easy to make my hair look fantastic! I bought the single shot at ULTA.

reviews.headline: Amazing
reviews.comments: love it so much, only thing i wish it came with is a travel bag/case because she is too precious

reviews.headline: I would NOT buy this product again
reviews.comments: I bought this about 2 months ago. Today it suddenly made a weird noise and started to smolder. For what you pay for this thing, it is NOT worth the money. Will not purchase again.

reviews.headline: STARTED SMOKING STOPPED WORKING
reviews.comments: I've had this product for around 2 years now, and it suddenly started smoking and stopped working. For what you pay for this, not worth it in my opinion. My 5 yr old revlon is still going strong and it was 1/3 of the cost ....

reviews.headline: So glad I finally got this round styler!!!
reviews.comments: I wanted to get a round styler brush to replace my Hot Tools oval one. Hairstylists at salons always use round brushes, not oval ones. Anyway, I finally pulled the trigger and I'm glad I did. I have very thick, wavy, more coarse blonde hair. I must say the first time I used this I could not be more impressed. Not only did it dry my hair, faster, but it gave me the curl at the bottom that I wasn't getting from my oval one. It also gave me a smoother more shiny blowout. I could not be more impressed and I highly recommend this single shot dryer styler. It's very easy to hold and it's lightweight which I also love.

reviews.headline: Loving the Smooth Silky Feel and Look
reviews.comments: Very easy to use and I like the heat/cool options.  Bristles are soft and comfortable.

reviews.headline: Best ROUND 2-in-1 Dryer Brush Out!
reviews.comments: Have the Dyson, Bondi Boost, Shark, L'Ange - yep all of them.  If you have thick curly hair that you straighten OR straighten Day 2 / 3 curls, THIS is it. Hot Air way less damaging than radiant heat / iron type tools. The brush is PART OF the end to end unit - this makes a difference! Many have the replaceable heads, which are good, but bend a bit. The shot series (specifically Single Shot ROUND brush) can get me from damp to bouncy shiny straight in 20 mins, dry curly to sexy straight in 10!! The larger oval brushes make hair too straight; this slightly, smaller and ROUND barrel gives great volume. With barrel part of unit, it's like part of your arm & you can move REALLY fast. And 1100 watts of power is perfect. Of the 7 I own, I literally use this on constant repeat!!!

reviews.headline: Love my single shot!
reviews.comments: I have the Revlon dryer brush which cost much less than this one.  It dries faster and gives a sleeker, shinier look.  I tried the single shot at my daughter's and fell in love.  My hair looks like it did years ago.  So much body and bounce!  I do use a hair dryer to get it a bit dry before I start.  I have had better results with Pantene mousse than styling spray.  I use a curling iron on my bangs and to get a bit of a bend at the roots.  So for me it isn't a one and done product but the results are phenominal and last.  If you're looking for a fast dry that results in a sleek look, go with the Revlon.  If you are looking for a more styled look that feels great, get the single shot.  Wait for a sale though.

reviews.headline: Dangerous Product, Horrible Customer Service
reviews.comments: I purchased this product a little over a year ago and it recently started smoking, which was very dangerous! I shipped my faulty product back to the company and they lost my package and refused to give me a refund/replacement.

reviews.headline: Ulta is no help
reviews.comments: I purchased this item in October. In March it just stopped working and won't even turn on. I know that this not within the normal return window but I thought since the item was defective and clearly meant to last longer than 5 months ulta would help make it right. I'm a long time consumer and this item wasn't cheap. Customer service wouldn't even hear me out. They just kept repeating it was past 30 days. Don't waste your money on expensive items here bc the big corporate company cares more about policies than helping customers.

reviews.headline: Highly Recommend
reviews.comments: It was time to replace my Revlon One Step hairdryer. I took a chance on this one in spite of the fact that it's more expensive. What I liked about it is a slightly smaller diameter barrel, and the fact that it's round and not oval shaped. It grips my thick hair well and make styling a breeze. My hair looks better using this one than my previous styling tool.

reviews.headline: Expensive but not quality
reviews.comments: I have had this for less than a year. Originally, I had the ConAir version and thought I would "upgrade" to the Drybar. It styles and dries nicely until the tips of the bristles come off and scratch your scalp while trying to dry the roots of your hair. I used it on the low heat setting, and it kept losing the yellow tips until they are all pretty much gone now.

reviews.headline: Fantastic before it shorts out!
reviews.comments: I now own my 4th Drybar roundbrush.  I absolutely love it.  Its dries my hair smooth and shiny. I've owned thd Dyson and Shark and like the Drybar best.   However, it is going to short circuit, you just dont know how long it will take.   The longest I've gone is a year.  Save your receipt.  Drybar is good anout replacing, but make sure you have annother dryer on hand because it takes a couple of weeks.

reviews.headline: Fantastic before it shorts out!
reviews.comments: I now own my 4th Drybar roundbrush.  I absolutely love it.  Its dries my hair smooth and shiny. I've owned thd Dyson and Shark and like the Drybar best.   However, it is going to short circuit, you just dont know how long it will take.   The longest I've gone is a year.  Save your receipt.  Drybar is good anout replacing, but make sure you have annother dryer on hand because it takes a couple of weeks.

reviews.headline: AMAZING!
reviews.comments: I highly recommend this hair tool to blow dry hair fast with beautiful shine. I wish there was a cold shot button versus a twist knob to set the hair for easier use but I have dried my hair 3 times with this and restyled once and absolutly love this! I feel like I'm finally able to give myself a blow out without breaking a sweat.

reviews.headline: So easy and fast
reviews.comments: I almost never wear my hair straight but I wanted the option to switch it up for special occasions or dry it quickly. I've never done a blowout on myself and this makes it so easy. I have 2b hair that is medium fine but very dense and a little past my shoulders. The first time I tried this I was done in under 20 minutes. It leaves my hair soft and smooth with some volume.

reviews.headline: Amazing dryer but doesn't last
reviews.comments: I have had two of these dryers.  The first one randomly stopped working mid dry but I loved it so much I got another one.  I have very long curly hair and I can get my super tight curls straight ans dry in about 10 minutes.  However my second one just suddenlt started to smell awful and poof motor died.  I cant bring myself to buy a third when both of the other two died before a year.

reviews.headline: Didn't dry my hair all the way
reviews.comments: I have thick hair and have owned the Revlon version and the Conair Knot Dr Dryer Hair Brush, both significantly cheaper and more effective. This just didn't dry my hair all the way despite it being only damp and me working on it a long time. Maybe if your hair isn't as thick as mine, it'll work well, but I gave it 2 tries and it's not worth the price so it's going back.

reviews.headline: this has got to be the best hot brush around! it is amazing.
reviews.comments: i love this brush!

reviews.headline: Bought it in Feb, stopped working in July
reviews.comments: I never write negative reviews but I was so disappointed with this. It worked so well until the motor gave out less than six months after purchase. I used it maybe once a week, it never traveled, was never dropped, nothing. For so much money, I expected better. Buyer beware I guess.

media.headline: Blowout virgin
media.caption: Shiny and smooth and so easy!

faceoff_positive.comments:
I purchased in-store because my friend had the Revlon version. She's got pin straight shoulder length hair though, and I really didn't trust it. I go to DryBar usually once a week, and the styles will last about 4 days with dry shampoo. I usually only wash my hair once a week, so it's something that works for me. I have hard water at home and the salon water makes my hair feel soft and refreshed.

My scalp has been increasing its dandruff production with summer though, and I've needed to wash 2x week now. 
The problem is I've never been able to recreate the blowout look at home, and I can't afford 2 blowouts a week. My hair is naturally curly, and I can style it just fine for curls, but I get really hot with my curls (I work in the medical field so I'm in surgical gown, scrubs, masks, face shield, and a really hot overhead light).
I've seen curly heads prefer this one to Revlon, and a girl at DryBar even told me it's because the Revlon isn't meant for wet hair, but this brush actually is. She said for the Revlon, I'd have to blow dry, straighten, then use it.
I'm the type of person, if I'm going to spend money on something I'd rather buy "the best" than buy the knockoff and eventually end up buying the better one. 
Also, this is a round circle brush compared to the Revlon oval and the DryBar oval double shot.
I've never used either, this is my 1st dryer brush.
I showered, used my DryBar liquid glass shampoo/conditioner because it smoothes my thick cuticles well. A lot of reviews/YouTubers said to not use it on dripping hair. I did what they typically do at DryBar. I wrung out my hair before twisting it in a microfiber towel. I tied the towel and my hair with a hair tie for about 10 minutes. It was damp but not dripping at all, I was honestly worried it was a little too dry. I sprayed prep rally detangle/heat protection spray and brushed it with a Tangle Teazer wet brush, sorry AND the drybar heat protection/quick dry serum. I probably could have just done the quick dry serum(2 pumps) but I didn't think about it until after the spray. With the quick dry serum and a normal blow dryer, it takes me 40 minutes to dry. Without the serum, we're looking at an hour. My hair is thick, curly, and to my mid back when straight/styled. 
A lot of people said to section your hair like you're curling or straightening it. 
Just WOW. 
I critiqued some YouTubers for flipping their hair different ways, at DryBar they blow dry it one direction (like you would curling/straightening), and it gives a nice half curl/flip at the ends. I don't think this brush could do that with my hair specifically. It probably would give nice curls/flip for shorter or straight hair. 
It would dry large sections 3-5inches across in about a minute. I HAD to use the brush both directions to dry the hair completely. I noticed my ends would dry before my roots, so I started letting it rest at the roots before dragging it down to the ends. It WILL get caught/stuck on your ends if you try to curl it too far up on the shaft. I could only flip it at the ends, and this I think is due to how the barrel is round/smaller than the double shot. 
So with sections, curling it both directions, I eventually turned my head upside down and used it like a hair brush to get my slightly damp scalp dry. It did the trick!
I had my whole head straight & voluminous after just 20 minutes. It had a slight curl on the ends but not what it gave a lot of straight/shorter hair. 
I sprayed DryBar hot toddy on my hair, heat protection but not a wet spray, dry like hairspray before I went over it with a 2" barrel curling iron from Kristin Ess. I notice that a 2" curling iron gives more of blowout curls than a wand. (I use a Paul Mitchell 1" flat iron, Paul Mitchell 1" wand or 1.25" Kristen Ess wand to do tighter curls depending on what type of curl I want.) I wanted more of a body wave than full curls. 
Did a full blowout and everything in 40 minutes! It looks amazing! For long curly hair, I think you won't get an immediate blowout from this, and I wanted to rate it 4 stars for myself, but it just got my hair dry so fast I don't think it deserves anything less than 5 stars. My hair was smooth and glossy too!

The brush DID NOT snag my hair like a YouTuber said it did her hair. I do wonder at how to clean the hair out of it over time though. It's just a few strands, but the bristles are course and hold onto it pretty good. I definitely recommend just trying to pull out what you can after each use. I'm THRILLED with being able to get great results on my 1st use. There's usually a learning curve.
faceoff_positive.headline: Not What I Was Expecting, But WOW!!

faceoff_negative.comments:
I tried the Single Shot because I love the Double Shot but hoped the Single Shot might give me a bit more curl at the ends.  It's possible that I could have gotten more curl from the Single Shot if I had been able to tolerate it long enough to really focus on trying to curl the ends, but two design flaws made the Single Shot very frustrating to use:  #1) The crease at the transition point between the handle and the barrel on the Single Shot kept catching and pulling my hair out (I don't have this problem with the Double Shot).  #2)  I found it much more difficult to rotate and maneuver the Single Shot in my hair vs. the Double Shot (I think the shape of the Double Shot tip is just an easier shape to grab with your second hand to help turn it as you run it through your hair).  

For those two reasons, I just wanted to get through the blowout with the Single Shot as quickly as possible and did not take the extra time to really focus on trying to get extra curl at the ends, so my end result with the Single Shot was pretty similar to the look I get with the Double Shot (nice and straight with just a little flip on the ends).  The Single Shot did deliver a nice, smooth blowout overall, much like the Double Shot.  But the Double Shot is MUCH more user friendly and does not have a crease that catches and pulls out my hair.  The possibility of a bit more curl from the Single Shot is just not worth it to me.  I highly recommend the Double Shot though!
faceoff_negative.headline: Not as good as the Double Shot

rollup.name: The Single Shot Round Blow-Dryer Brush
